Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, 222 South Tianshui Road, Lanzhou 730000, China ⁎ Corresponding author. An organoselenium-catalyzed oxidative exo-selective ring-closing reaction of unsaturated alcohol promoted by 1-fluoropyridinium triflate (FP-OTf), N-fluorobenzenesulfonimide (NFSI) and Selectfluor has been theoretically studied. The reaction mechanisms were proposed after detailed computational screening, the corresponding potential Gibbs energy surfaces were drawn, and catalytic cycles were proposed. The conjugation effect in ring-closing transition state structure determined the reaction exo-/endo- selectivity, and the intramolecular steric repulsion in β-elimination transition state structure determined the reaction (E)-/(Z)- selectivity. The influence of oxidant species and addition of NaF on the reaction yield was discussed in detail. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Theoretical calculation Organoselenium catalysis Oxidant Reaction mechanism Selectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the past two decades, organoselenium catalysis has been widely applied in organic transformations [1-5], the chiral selenium catalysts can promote asymmetric reactions with high stereoseletivity [2,3,5-7]. The selenium-π-acid catalyzed oxidative alkene functionalization reactions has drawn increasing attentions in recent years [1]. The oxidative cyclization reactions of unsaturated carboxylic acids were developed by Wirth and co-workers [8,9], and the corresponding asymmetric reaction was reported by Maruoka's group [10]. The oxidative vinyl CH functionalization reactions were investigated by Zhao's group [11-13], Breder's group [14], Chen's group [15] and Yang's group [16], respectively. The oxidative allylic functionalization reactions of alkene were developed by Wirth's group [17] and Zhao's group [18,19]. Denmark and co-workers have investigated the stereo-specific syn-dichlorination of alkenes [20,21], and the enantioselective syn-bifunctionalization reaction of alkenes [22,23]. Besides, the Se-π-acid catalyzed oxidative functionalization of alkynes and allenes were also studied by Zhao's group [24] and Almendros’ group [25], respectively. Selenide is usually selected as pre-catalyst, however the oxidants are various, the N-F reagents such as NFSI [10-12,14,15], 1-F-pyridine and analogues [13,16,18-25] and Selectfluor [24] are most widely-used; Besides, persulfate oxidant (NH4)2S2O8 [17] and hypervalent I(III) oxidants such as PhI(OOCCF3)2 [8,9] are also effective oxidants in certain cases. Theoretical calculation has been popular in both organoselenium catalysts and relative reactions in recent studies. In organoselenium catalyst research, Breder's group [26] have performed DFT calculation to find out the most possible active organoselenium catalytic species, Yeung and co-workers [27] have theoretically studied the nonclassical hydrogen bond (NCHB) catalyst based on cyclopropenium selenium dihalides. In reaction mechanism research, Yeung and co-workers have theoretically studied the mechanism of organoselenium-catalyzed electrophilic halogenation reaction [28], the mechanisms of some Se…O chalcogen bond-catalyzed reactions were also investigated by DFT calculations [29-33]. The theoretical studies on selenium-π-acid catalyzed oxidative alkene functionalization reactions were also reported, but the amount is much smaller than corresponding experimental studies. Breder's group [1] have proposed basic catalytic principles. Almendros’ group [25] have investigated the reaction mechanism of the Se-π-acid complex formation by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, they found that the sp 3-O atom in substrate can form Se…O non-covalent interaction to stabilize transition state and Se-π-acid complex, the stronger Se…O non-covalent interaction will make the reaction more energetically and kinetically favorable. Yang and co-workers [16] have investigated the detailed mechanism of the organoselenium-catalzyed desymmetrizing oxidative cyclization reaction of prochiral substrate (E)-bis(2-hydroxyphenyl) (styryl)phosphine oxide by DFT calculations, the reaction proceeded via diselenide oxidation→Se-π-acid complex formation→ion-pair formation→ring-closing and selenide oxidation→OTf−-assisted β-elimination procedures, they found that more intermolecular hydrogen-bonds can lower the Gibbs energies of both ion-pair and stereo-determining transition state, further leading to high stereoselectivity. There are some problems remain unsolved in current studies: (1) It is hard to figure out the most possible active catalysis species for a certain reaction [11,19]. (2) The influence of oxidant species on reaction yields are significant but rarely studied, the researchers need to try different oxidants randomly to screen out the most ideal one [10,12,15,16,18,19]. In 2016, Zhao and co-workers [18] have reported an organoselenium-catalyzed oxidative exo-selective ring-closing reaction of unsaturated alcohols (80 % R + 20% R') promoted by 1-fluoropyridinium triflate (FP-OTf), N-fluorobenzenesulfonimide (NFSI) and Selectfluor, as shown in Table 1 . The reaction has high exo-/endo- and (E)-/(Z)- selectivities, (E)-P(5) is the main product, and P(7) is originated form (E)-P(5) or (Z)-P(5) catalyzed by H+ [18]. Different oxidants and the addition of NaF can greatly influence the reaction yields. The N-F reagents such as FP-OTf and NFSI are effective oxidants for the reaction leading to almost the same total yields (Entries 2 and 3); Selectfluor is also N-F reagent, however the corresponding total yield is much lower (Entry 4); The persulfate oxidant (NH4)2S2O8 and hypervalent I(III) iodine oxidants such as PhI(OAc)2, PhI(OOCCF3)2 cannot promote the reaction; the peroxide oxidant UHP (hydrogen peroxide-urea adduct) resulted to low total yield (Entries 5∼8). The addition of NaF will obviously improve the total reaction yield and inhibit the formation of P(7) (Entry 1). This reaction aroused our great interest, and some questions need to be solved: (1) What is the most possible active Se catalytic species in each Entry? (2) What is the detailed reaction mechanism? (3) What is the origin of exo-/endo- selectivity and (E)-/(Z)- selectivity? (4) How did NaF improve the reaction yield? (5) NFSI and FP-OTF have different molecular structures, why did they lead to almost the same total reaction yields? (6) Why did Selectfluor lead to much lower total yield than those of NFSI and FP-OTF? Therefore, we have carried out theoretical studies on the reactions depicted in Table 1, Entries 1∼4 to solve these 6 questions. We hope our study could provide some valuable insights and basis for further studies on organoselenium-catalyzed oxidative reactions, such as figuring out the most possible active catalysis species in different cases, revealing the influence of oxidant species and additive NaF on reaction yields, and offering some guidance for selecting suitable oxidant in organoselenium-catalyzed oxidative reactions. 2 Computational details Geometry optimizations of all structures were performed at PBE0 [34] -D3 [35] (BJ) [36-38] /Def2-SVP [39] /SMD [40] (acetonitrile) level of theory. Vibrational frequencies were calculated at the same level of theory to verify each transition state (TS) structure has only one imaginary frequency, while the other structures have no imaginary frequency, and Gibbs energy correction (GEC) of each structure was obtained. Intrinsic reaction coordination (IRC) [41,42] calculation was performed at the same level of theory to ensure each TS structure connected corresponding reactant and product. Single-point energy (E) calculation was performed at PBE0-D3(BJ)/Def2-TZVP [39] /SMD(acetonitrile) level of theory, the Gibbs energy (G) was calculated as follows: G=GEC+E. Geometry optimizations, vibrational frequency calculations and IRC calculations were carried out using Gaussian 16 C.01 software package [43]. In the reaction selectivity study, distortion-interaction analysis [44-46] can reveal how molecule distortion and intermolecular interaction influence transition state energy [47-51], Hirshfeld atomic charge calculation can estimate the molecule charge distribution [52], and non-covalent interaction (NCI) analysis [53,54] can make non-covalent interaction measurable and visible [48,51,55,56]. In this study, distortion-interaction analysis was carried out at PBE0-D3(BJ)/Def2-TZVP/SMD(acetonitrile) level of theory; Hirshfeld atomic charge calculation and NCI analysis were performed using Multiwfn 3.8 (dev) software [57] using the wavefunctions obtained from single-point energy calculation. The rate-determining step identification and activation Gibbs energy calculation were carried out following the Murdoch's [58] study. The optimized structures were drawn using CYLview software [59], and the NCI analysis results were displayed using Chemcraft software [60]. 3 Results and discussions We proposed a general catalytic cycle displayed in Fig. 1 , which can be divided into 4 Stages. Stage 1: the PhSeSePh reacts with oxidant to generate active catalytic species [Se]n+-cat; Stage 2: reactant R or R' can join the reaction to form Se-π acid complex for the preparation of ring-closing reaction, subsequently the CO bond is formed to generate selenide; Stage 3: an oxidation reaction occurs to convert selenide into oxidized selenide; Stage 4: a base-promoted β-elimination reaction takes place to release (E)-P(5) and regenerate [Se]n+-cat. The n th (n ≥ 2) catalytic cycle only proceeds via 3 stages—Stage 2, Stage 3 and Stage 4. The aggregation states of some small molecules are significant to setting Gibbs energy reference, which are listed in Fig. S1. In some cases F− is necessary to Stage 4, we have proposed several possible reactions providing F− , which are discussed in Fig. S2 and Table S1. There are multiple reaction pathways in Stages 2 and 4, which are screened carefully before proposing reaction mechanism (See SI). 3.1 Reaction mechanism of entry 1 According to Wynn and co-workers’ study [61], there is low concentration of F− when adding NaF to MeCN, therefore in Entry 1 the free F− is considered as reactant in our mechanism study. We have carefully screened out the most possible pathway (Figs. S3∼S5), and the R-participated reaction mechanism of the 1st catalytic cycle of Entry 1 is proposed, the reaction potential Gibbs energy surface is depicted in Fig. 2 , it is PhSeOTf rather than PhSeF which participates the reaction (see SI, Section 4.1). First in Stage 1, diselenide PhSeSePh is oxidized by FP+ via TS1 to generate Se(IV) species PhSe+(F)-SePh (denoted as Int1). Afterwards in Stage 2, Int1 captures OTf− anion to form Int2, then Int2 decomposes to PhSeF and PhSeOTf, PhSeOTf acts as active catalytic species to combine with R to generate Se-π acid complex A-Int3-a1, subsequently ion-pair A-Int3-a3 is formed, then the 5-membered ring-closing reaction occurs via A-TS2-a3 to generate selenide Int5. Next in Stage 3, selenide Int5 is oxidized by FP+ via TS2 to generate Se(IV) species Int6. At last in Stage 4, F− anion abstracts β-H, which triggering intermolecular β-elimination reaction via TS4-(E)(inter-F−−1) (or TS4-(Z)(inter-F−−1)) to produce (E)-P(5) (or (Z)-P(5)), HF and PhSeF. ΔG(TS4-(Z)(inter-F−−1)) is 1.1 kcal•mol−1 higher than ΔG(TS4-(E)(inter-F−−1)), indicating that (E)-P(5) is generated faster than (Z)-P(5). The theoretically calculated (E)-/(Z)- selectivity is in agreement with experimental result, although it is underestimated (See SI, Section 8). For the whole reaction, the rate-determining step is PhSeSePh→A-TS1 procedure in Stage 1, the activation Gibbs energy is 26.3 kcal•mol−1. For the n th (n ≥ 2) catalytic cycle of R-participated reaction and the n th (n = 1, 2, 3…) catalytic cycle of R'-participated reaction of Entry 1, their potential Gibbs energy surfaces are depicted in Figs. S8∼S10. Based on the reaction mechanisms, a simplified catalytic cycle of R-participated reaction of Entry 1 is shown in Fig. 3 , while the detailed ones of both R- and R'- participated reactions are shown in Figs. S11 and S12, respectively. In the 1st catalytic cycle, PhSeSePh is converted into PhSeOTf, then the reaction goes through PhSeSePh→→PhSeOTf→→A-Int3-a3→Int5→Int6→(E)-P(5) + PhSeF + HF procedure; The 2nd catalytic cycle can only be promoted by PhSeF (See SI, Section 4.3.1), it goes through PhSeF→→A-Int3-b3→Int5→Int6→(E)-P(5) + PhSeF + HF procedure. 3.2 Reaction mechanism of entry 2 Entry 2, Stage 1 is the same as Entry 1, Stage 1. We have screened out the possible reaction pathways in Entry 2, Stage 4 (See Figs. S13 and S14). After screening, we propose the reaction mechanisms for both R- and R'-participated reactions, the corresponding potential Gibbs energy surfaces are depicted in Figs. S15∼S22. We have proposed a simplified catalytic cycle of R-participated reaction of Entry 2 (Fig. 4 ), there are 3 different kinds of reaction pathways. The 1st catalytic cycle is promoted by PhSeOTf (See SI, Section 5.3.1), it goes through PhSeSePh→→A-Int3-a3→Int5→Int6 →TS4-(E)(inter-Py-1)→(E)-P(5) + PhSeF procedure; The 2nd catalytic cycle can be promoted by either PhSeOTf or PhSeF (See SI, Section 5.3.2), it goes through PhSeF→→A-Int3→Int5→Int6→TS4-(E)(intra)→PhSeF + (E)-P(5) + Int3 procedure; While the n th (n ≥ 3) catalytic cycle goes through Int3→A-Int3→Int5→Int6→Int7→TS4-(E)(intra)→PhSeF + (E)-P(5) + Int3 procedure, PhSeF is firstly consumed and then regenerated in Stage 4. In Gramage-Doria and co-workers’ study, the change of base species will change the reaction mechanism, finally leading to different product [62]; While comparing Entries 1 and 2 of our study, the addition of NaF will also change the reaction mechanism (mainly β-elimination step), leading to lower activation Gibbs energy, faster reaction rate and higher yield of the same product (E)-P(5). 3.3 Reaction mechanism entry 3 For R-participated reaction of Entry 3, the most favorable reaction pathway is screened out (Figs. S25∼S27), the active catalytic species is PhSeN(SO2Ph)2 (See SI, Section 6.1), further we propose the reaction mechanism, the potential Gibbs energy surface of the 1st catalytic cycle is depicted in Fig. 5 . Firstly PhSeSePh is oxidized by NFSI via B-TS1 to generate Int1, then Int1 captures N(SO2Ph)2 − anion to form B-Int2, followed by the release of PhSeF to generate PhSeN(SO2Ph)2 . Afterwards PhSeN(SO2Ph)2 combines with R to form B-Int3-a1 and B-Int3-a3 successively, and 5-membered ring-closing procedure occurs via B-TS2-a3 to produce Int5. Subsequently Int5 is oxidized by NFSI via B-TS3 to generate Int6, then intermolecular β-elimination reaction occurs via TS4-(E)(inter-N(SO2Ph)2 −−1) or TS4-(Z)(inter-N(SO2Ph)2 −−1) to generate (E)-P(5) or (Z)-P(5), respectively. Finally the by-products PhSeF reacts with HN(SO2Ph)2 to form PhSeN(SO2Ph)2 and HF spontaneously (Fig. S1), and PhSeN(SO2Ph)2 can join another catalytic cycle. TS4-(E)(inter-N(SO2Ph)2 −−1) has lower Gibbs energy than TS4-(Z)(inter-N(SO2Ph)2 −−1), indicating (E)-P(5) can be produced faster than (Z)-P(5), which is in agreement with experimental result; Similar to Entry 1, the calculated (E)-/(Z)- selectivity is qualitatively correct, but lower than the experimental result (See SI, Section 8). The rate-determining step is Int6→TS4-(E)(inter-N(SO2Ph)2 −−1) procedure, and the activation Gibbs energy ΔG act=26.0 kcal•mol−1. The potential Gibbs energy surface of the n th (n ≥ 2) catalytic cycle is shown in Fig. S28. The Gibbs energy surfaces of R'-participated reactions are shown in Fig. S29 and S30. The simplified catalytic cycle of Entry 3 is proposed in Fig. 6 . In the 1st catalytic cycle, the reaction goes through Stage 1→Stage 2→Stage 3→Stage 4 to produce (E)-P(5), PhSeF and HN(SO2Ph)2 , afterwards PhSeF reacts with HN(SO2Ph)2 to generate PhSeN(SO2Ph)2 and HF; While the n th (n ≥ 2) catalytic cycle starts from PhSeN(SO2Ph)2 and goes through Stage 2→Stage 3→Stage 4, PhSeF is generated in Stage 4 and soon converted to PhSeN(SO2Ph)2 . The detailed catalytic cycles of both R- and R'-participated reactions of Entry 3 are depicted in Figs. S31 and S32, respectively. 3.4 Reaction mechanism of entry 4 After reaction pathway screening (see Figs. S33∼S35), we find that in Entry 4 it is PhSe+(F)-SePh (also denoted as Int1) which catalyzes the reaction in Stage 2 (see SI, Section 7.1). We have proposed the reaction mechanism of the 1st catalytic cycle of Entry 4, the potential Gibbs energy surface is shown in Fig. 7 . First PhSeSePh is oxidized by [C7H14ClN2-F]2+ via C-TS1 to generate Int1, then Int1 combines with R to form Se-π acid complex Int3-c1, followed by the formation of Int3-c2. Afterwards the 5-membered ring-closing reaction takes place via C-TS2-c2 to generate Int4-c2, then a reductive elimination reaction occurs via TS2-cc to produce Int5 and PhSeF. Subsequently, Int5 is oxidized by [C7H14ClN2-F]2+ via C-TS3 to generate Int6. (E)-P(5) can be produced via Int6→Int7→TS4-(E)(intra)→(E)-P(5) pathway with 27.6 kcal•mol−1 activation Gibbs energy, while (Z)-P(5) can be produced via Int6→TS4-(Z)(inter-[C7H14ClN2]+−1)→(Z)-P(5) pathway with 31.3 kcal•mol−1 activation Gibbs energy, which is kinetically unfavorable. The calculation result indicates highly (E)-selective of the reaction, which in agreement with experimental result. For the nth (n ≥ 2) catalytic cycle of '-participated reaction and the nth (n = 1, 2, 3…) catalytic cycle of R'-participated reaction of Entry 4, their potential Gibbs energy surfaces are depicted in Figs. S36-S38. For R-participated reaction of Entry 4, a simplified catalytic cycle is proposed in Fig. 8 . The reaction goes through Stage 1→Stage 2→Stage 3 procedure to generate Int6, then Int6 reacts with PhSeF and R to produce Int7 and Int3, Int7 goes through TS4-(E)(intra) to form (E)-P(5), PhSeF and HF; While the n th (n ≥ 2) catalytic cycle starts from Int3 and goes through Stage 2→Stage 3→Stage 4, PhSeF is firstly consumed and then regenerated in Stage 4. The detailed catalytic cycles of both R- and R'-participated reactions of Entry 4 are depicted in Figs. S39 and S40, respectively. 3.5 Origin of exo-/endo- and (E)-/(Z)- selectivity 3.5.1 The exo-/endo- selectivity of ring-closing reaction Referring to A-TS2-a3 leading to exo-ring-closing product, we propose a transition state A-TS2(endo)-a3 which leading to endo-ring-closing product (Fig. 9 ). TS2(endo)-a3 has obviously higher Gibbs energy than A-TS2-a3 (Fig. 9), indicating the exo-ring-closing is kinetically favorable, which is in agreement with experimental results. However, what is the origin of exo-/endo- selectivity? We have carried out a series of computational studies (see SI, Section 9). There is a large amount of positive charge on PhSe+ moiety, the breaking of C-Se bond will greatly increase the positive charge of C atom. In A-TS2-a3, the positive charge on C1 atom can be delocalized to Ph group by means of p-π conjugation effect, leading to lower energy of A-TS2-a3; While in A-TS2(endo)-a3, there is no p-π conjugation between C2 atom and -CH2CH2Ph group, the -CH2CH2Ph group can only stabilize positive charge from C2 atom by inductive effect, which is much less effective than conjugation effect, finally leading to higher energy of A-TS2(endo)-a3. 3.5.2 The (E)-/(Z)- selectivity of β-elimination In Entries 1∼4, ΔG(TS4-(Z)(inter-base-1)) > ΔG(TS4-(E)(inter-base-1)) and ΔG(TS4-(Z)(intra)) > ΔG(TS4-(E)(intra)) (base=F− , pyridine, N(SO2Ph)2 − ), (Figs. 2, S15, 5 and S16), the (E)-/(Z)- selectivity of β-elimination has no relationship with inter-/intramolecular reaction type or base species. Therefore the (E)-/(Z)- selectivity should be controlled by some general factors. We have performed NCI analysis for the structures of TS4-(E)(intra), TS4-(Z)(intra), TS4-(E)(inter-base-1), and TS4-(Z)(inter-base-1) (base=F− , pyridine, N(SO2Ph)2 − ), the summarized results are shown in Fig. 10 . TS4-(E)(intra) and TS4-(Z)(intra) have similar H…H steric repulsions, however TS4-(Z)(intra) has an extra C…O steric repulsion, leading to higher energy; TS4-(Z)(inter-base-1) always has smaller H…H distance and larger steric repulsions than corresponding TS4-(E)(inter-base-1) (base=F− , pyridine, N(SO2Ph)2 − ), which is responsible for higher energy (See Fig. S43 for more details). In summary, the intramolecular steric repulsion determines the (E)-/(Z)- selectivity of β-elimination reaction. Similarly to our previous study, we have found that intramolecular steric repulsion can determine the enantioselectivity of asymmetric semipinacol rearrangement reaction [51]. 3.6 The origin of total reaction yield differences between entries 1∼4 In order to reveal the origin of total reaction yield difference, we have analyzed the most possible active catalytic species, potential Gibbs energy surfaces and activation Gibbs energies (ΔG acts) of all catalytic cycles in Entries 1∼4 (See SI for more details), and the total reaction yields have been investigated. The results are summarized in Table 2 . For both R- and R'-participated reactions of Entry 1, all catalytic cycles are kinetically favorable, leading to highest total reaction yield (92 %). For R-participated reaction in Entry 2, all catalytic cycles are kinetically favorable; While for R'-participated reaction in Entry 2, only 1st catalytic cycle is kinetically favorable, the ΔG act of the n th (n ≥ 2) catalytic cycle is too high to overcome (34.2 kcal•mol−1), indicating the 79 % total yield is most contributed by R-participated reaction, Entry 2 has lower total reaction yield than Entry 1 due to the low conversion of R'. All catalytic cycles of Entry 3 have lower ΔG acts than those of Entry 2, it seems that Entry 3 is more kinetically favorable, why the total yield of Entry 3 is only comparable to that of Entry 2 (78% vs 79 %)? We speculate it could be attributed to the acidity of reaction system. Entry 3 can produce both HN(SO2Ph)2 and HF (Fig. 6), while Entry 2 can only produce HF (Fig. 4), the acidity of HN(SO2Ph)2 is much stronger than HF (Fig. S1). As the reaction proceeds, the reaction system of Entry 3 will accumulate large amounts of both HN(SO2Ph)2 and HF, the acids (especially HN(SO2Ph)2 ) might combine with N(SO2Ph)2 − or intermediate such as Int6, which retarding the reaction from going through β-elimination (rate-determining step, see Figs. 5, S28, S29, S30). Further study is needed to answer the question in detail. High ΔG acts of Entry 4 should be responsible for its lowest total yield (16 %). For R-participated reaction, the 1st catalytic cycle could contribute at most 10 % total reaction yield because 10 mol% PhSeSePh is used; However in the n th (n ≥ 2) catalytic cycle, due to the lack of suitable proton acceptor, the ΔG act of R-participated reaction is much higher (29.9 kcal•mol−1), resulting to low conversion of R; While for R'-participated reaction, the reactant R' can hardly be converted to product (E)-P(5) due to high ΔG act (≥29.3 kcal•mol−1). Interestingly, Entry 3 has higher yield of P(7) than Entry 2, and there is no P(7) in Entry 1 (Table 1), what is the origin of P(7) yield difference? We think it could also be attributed to the acidity of reaction system. The conversion from (E)-P(5) to P(7) is H +-catalyzed, as we discussed above, the reaction system of Entry 3 is much more acidic than that of Entry 2, resulting to higher yield of P(7); As for Entry 1 the free F − can combine with HF spontaneously (Fig. S1), the reaction system is less acidic than that of Entry 2, which could be responsible for 0 % yield of P(7). 4 Conclusions In summary, we have theoretically studied an organoselenium-catalyzed oxidative ring-closing reaction of unsaturated alcohol promoted by 3 different N-F oxidants: FP-OTf, NFSI and Selectfluor. The reaction mechanisms are proposed after detailed computational screening, the corresponding potential Gibbs energy surfaces are drawn, and catalytic cycles are proposed. When using different oxidants, the active catalytic species could be either PhSeX ( X =OTf, F, N(SO2Ph)2 ) or Ph-Se+(F)-SePh cation. The reaction of the 1st catalytic cycle goes through 4 stages: Stage 1——Oxidation of PhSeSePh; Stage 2——Ring-closing reaction; Stage 3——Oxidation of selenide; Stage 4——inter- or intramolecular β-elimination to generate final product (E)-P(5); While the n th (n ≥ 2) catalytic cycle only goes through Stages 2, 3 and 4, in Entries 1, 2 and 4 the reaction mechanisms of Stages 2, 3 and 4 are different between the 1st and the n th (n ≥ 2) catalytic cycles. The conjugation effect between C1 atom and Ph group in A-TS2-a3 determines the exo-selectivity of the reaction. The intramolecular steric repulsion in TS structure of Stage 4 determines the reaction (E)-/(Z)- selectivity. Entry 2 has lower yield than Entry 1, because the conversion of R' in the n th (n ≥ 2) catalytic cycle will be kinetically unfavorable without free F −. Entry 3 is more kinetically favorable than Entry 2 but they have comparable yields, the possible reason is that the by-product HN(SO2Ph)2 could combine with N(SO2Ph)2 − or intermediate such as Int6, which retarding the reaction from going through β-elimination. Entry 4 has the lowest yield, the R-participated reaction is very slow in the n th (n ≥ 2) catalytic cycle due to the lack of a suitable proton acceptor, leading to ΔG act rise and R conversion decrease; While R' can hardly be converted in all catalytic cycles due to high ΔG act. For Entries 1∼3, the stronger acidity of reaction system will lead to higher yield of P(7). (NH4)2S2O8 17 and PhI(OOCCF3)2 8, 9 are effective oxidants in reported organoselenium-catalyzed reactions, however they cannot promote the reaction in Table 1, the underlying reasons will be investigated in further study, which is helpful for understanding the influence of different oxidants on organoselenium-catalyzed reactions. coredata.dc:description: An organoselenium-catalyzed oxidative exo-selective ring-closing reaction of unsaturated alcohol promoted by 1-fluoropyridinium triflate (FP-OTf), N-fluorobenzenesulfonimide (NFSI) and Selectfluor has been theoretically studied. The reaction mechanisms were proposed after detailed computational screening, the corresponding potential Gibbs energy surfaces were drawn, and catalytic cycles were proposed. The conjugation effect in ring-closing transition state structure determined the reaction exo-/endo- selectivity, and the intramolecular steric repulsion in β-elimination transition state structure determined the reaction (E)-/(Z)- selectivity. The influence of oxidant species and addition of NaF on the reaction yield was discussed in detail.

coredata.dc:title: Both N-F oxidant and NaF determined reaction yield in the organoselenium-catalyzed oxidative ring-closing reaction of unsaturated alcohol: A theoretical study
